Message.Title: $99 tablet coming out by Google
Message.Msg: Google is working on a new model of its well-received Nexus 7 tablet that will cost $99, according to a DigiTimes report. The tablet is said to launch in the fourth quarter of this year. There will also be a $199 model of the device, according to the report. (The current Nexus 7 also starts at $199.) The timing lines up with Apple's expected release of a smaller iPad, the so-called iPad Mini. Apple has all but confirmed it will announce the iPad Mini at a press event in October. Many think the iPad Mini will be priced around $250. Today's $199 Nexus 7 is a great tablet. If Google can find a way to offer the same experience for just $99, it's going to be tough for people to pass up.

Topic.Title: Is there a way to straight up short this stock, not through options?

Message.Msg: Your best choice is options. When you short the stock, you have borrowing fees. If you write a deep In-The-Money Call, that would effectively be a short with the added bonus of time being in your favor. You can do options a year out which would give you what you want. However, be careful - as with any trade know what you are doing and plan your trade and trade your plan.

Topic.Title: Is there a way to straight up short this stock, not through options?

Message.Msg: The problem with options is they expire. I would like to just hold this short until it crashes, which it will do in time. Its just hard to know when. I understand what you are saying though. I didn't realize there were borrowing fees, so that makes a difference. I just feel like its hard to do well in options unless you get lucky. Each option is pretty expensive, so you have to get a big move for it to make you money.

Topic.Title: Is there a way to straight up short this stock, not through options?

Message.Msg: Just make sure you have cash in your account to cover the current market value of the short position and there should not be any borrowing fees. In other words, do not invest the proceeds you receive from the naked short.

Topic.Title: Vendor Loans...is a precursor to AMZN justifying their borrowing money

Message.Msg: I believe this is the main reason for the drastic move today. The number one problem in the short term for AMZN, even bigger than their failed Kindle Fire strategy, was their shrinking current ratio and most likely need for a debt offering. This would have blown a hole in the AMZN "cash cow" story currently being peddled by the lazy/corrupt Wall Street analyst community. The vendor financing does indeed give them cover to borrow money from the markets, without immediately blowing up the stock. So perversely, risk of the financing event is temporarily off the table. Although the fundamentals of lending money to sub-standard vendors at usury rates is not a good thing.

Topic.Title: Vendor Loans...is a precursor to AMZN justifying their borrowing money

Message.Msg: Vendor loans were ultimately the undoing of Nortel. Revenue growth was fueled in part by vendor financing. When those vendors ran into trouble, the hit to Nortel was two-fold. Revenues dried up and collection of those receivables came into question as vendors went belly-up.

Topic.Title: Vendor Loans...is a precursor to AMZN justifying their borrowing money

Message.Msg: It's a repeat of the housing bubble. Only difference is that Scamazon is forking out up-front $ on unsecured loans. If Scamazon can't turn a profit with its own $, then loaning $ to a middle man will make the process even more difficult. Stupid shareholders will be on the hook for massive losses. With the rate at 0%, legitimate sellers don't have problem with financing. It's the high-risk vendors that will put Scamazon in BK land.

Topic.Title: Vendor Loans...is a precursor to AMZN justifying their borrowing money

Message.Msg: This should scare the crap out of "investors". There are plenty of financial institutions that have built a competence assessing credit risk. This just exposes AMZN to huge financial risk, further levering it as we head into the recession. For those who don't understand, GDP is growing at 1% with the Federal government running a deficit that is about 10% of GDP. Y= C+I+G+X-M. Google it. If we were running a balanced budget, GDP would be massively negative and we would be in a Depression. Even slowing the deficit growth, which is the minimum that will happen, puts us into recession... Pump all you want. I will be adding...

Pump with dump flips..fast and furious is great ............ you pumper shills will soon learn what "jump you $ucker song for wall street means on youtube How Wall Street Scams Counties Into Bankruptcy By William D. Cohan Jul 1, 2012 3:30 PM PT "Inside Job" Director Charles Ferguson: Wall Street Has Turned the U.S. into a "Predatory Nation" ROME DID NOT BURN I A DAY A Lonely Redemption He is no less suspicious of Goldman Sachs, which has alumni sprinkled across the upper reaches of government. In a tough spot, Goldman obtained extraordinary permission to make an overnight metamorphosis from investment bank to traditional bank holding company. “Can I prove this was a wired deal? Absolutely not,” Mr. Lewis said. “Am I certain of it? Only 100 percent.” As for the whirling, three-million-shares-per-second casino of Wall Street? He sees it as rigged. “I would not risk stocks under any circumstances,” he said, “because we don’t know when this thing is going to blow.” Nothing about Mr. Lewis is easy. He delights in sending scabrous, insulting, free-associative mass e-mails to journalists, financiers and members of Congress. Show annoyance, and he doubles down. “You know what I do with tension?” he said. “I ratchet it up!”

Message.Title: when do you try and start a new business
Message.Msg: when the business you are in ain't profitable the add-on businesses aren't a value add service, they are an attempt to find a way to make money. a sales tax free book/dvd/cd business wide selection business was profitable.....the transition away from that has not been........the wine business and finance biz is not genius but a desperate way to take the goodwill they have cultivated and try to make a profit.....somehow! Basically they are trying to be Ebay......a good biz but not at this price.

Topic.Title: Vendor Loans...is a precursor to AMZN justifying their borrowing money

Message.Msg: "RPT-Intel zeroes in on enterprise customers with first tablet wave..." You mean from that company this is down to $20 from its all-time high over a decade ago of $60. Probably another of his "great" investments (duds). "creating yet more competition for Amazon's proprietary piece" Too bad they don't have the content ecosystem to match. "And the best part is that Bezos wants to take on credit risk right now." Much less risky if you understand seasonal cashflows in the retail business the way Amazon does better than anyone else. And have direct access to the business flow and real time transaction records (their businesses by definition run on Amazon's platform) of the loan holders. Plus, as a kind of collateral whatever they purchase with the loans remains in Amazon's distribution centers anyway. Risk? From a guy who took the risk most recently of shorting this stock at $230? Maybe he needs to take a look a his own stupidity first.
